lines.text: Betrayed by a white man, cast out by her own people, the Cherokee squaw wanders along the Sierra forests.
I give him back to his father's people. Make of him a white man.
An Indian can't hold land in this country. You've got to get out.
You know - all play and no pray makes Jack a dull boy.

Pastor Wynn's motherless daughter. Expensively educated, she was profoundly ignorant in two languages, with a trained misunderstanding of music and painting, and a natural and faultless taste in dress.

[to The Half-Breed]
I hope that our kindness has not led you to consider that you are as good as your betters. In the future, try to remember that, after all, you are an Indian.
She's a white woman, you're an Indian. You know what that means here.
My father was a white man.
That may be true, but there are all kinds of white men.
And at this point in our story, there butted into Excelsior a new specimen of the superior race; this was Dick Curson, who lived chiefly upon the credulity of the ignorant Indians.

[to Teresa]
You damn trash! I'm through with you!
Come on out, you little devil!
I thought hounding Indians was your speed.
Aw, come on, Teresa, if you're nice to me you might find the caboose door open some night.
Come and take me if you dare!
I heard the rustle of your skirts against the leaves.
